title: Tuesday, 8th December, 2015

11:01 am

PM

Yes

my word

11:04 am
BE

It can be argued that the shrinking influence of miners shows how efficient the FTSE 100 is, as an index.

PM

As in kills the duds?

BE

Yup. I've spent at least a decade writing about how the FTSE is an emerging-markets-exposed, commodity driven, dollar dependent gauge of nothing much.

11:04 am
BE

And it's not true.

BE

At least, it's not true now. Oil exposure's still notable, but in terms of the miners: meh.

PM

Suddenly supported by the grocers, of al things

11:05 am
BE

Yeah. Anyway, quick damage report.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 78.61, down 6.75 (-7.91%), High: 84.42, Low: 78.41, Volume: 24.49m

scorchedfingers scorchedfingers scorchedfingers scorchedfingers

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 724.97, down 40.23 (-5.26%), High: 746.20, Low: 721.70, Volume: 4.91m
BE

And Anglo, of course, which chose a bad day to try and bury bad news.

11:06 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 339.90, down 29.1 (-7.89%), High: 365.00, Low: 332.35, Volume: 9.44m
BE

It's difficult to say whether, in a flat market, Anglo would be up, down or sideways on this restructuring plan.

BE

The divi's gone. Of course. There was never a doubt about that.

11:08 am
PM

Gone for the forseeable, which wasnt quite foreseen

BE

They're reducing from 55 "assets" to 20 "core priority one" mines that'll be cashflow generative through the cycle.

BE

As in, shrinking by 60% in terms of assets.

11:09 am
BE

But not in terms of staff. 135,000 employees going to 92,000 by the end of 2017.

BE

Vague target of 50,000 eventually. One has to wonder why Anglo was so poorly constructed for "the cycle" previous to this morning.

BE

So anyway. Anglo's now going to be De Beers, Industrial Metals and Bulk Commodities.

11:10 am
BE

Sellside is divided. Half of them are saying "this is more aggressive than we envisaged" and the other half are saying "this isn't aggressive enough."

PM

well, takes two views to make a market

BE

Indeed so. One of them is Fraser Jamieson at Cazenove, who's been an Anglo bear for approximately forever.

11:11 am
BE

Nothing said today changes his mind.

BE

Anglo American has announced a further portfolio restructuring as part of
today’s Strategy Day. In our view, $2.1bn of additional opex savings across
2016-17 (6% of COGS), plus $1.0bn of capex cuts should see AAL’s shares
react positively in the near term. However, these measures do not go far
enough to challenge our fundamentally bearish view. Specifically, in the
absence of higher commodity prices, a significant reduction in net debt from
~$13bn at YE’15 (34% gearing) will only be achieved by a more aggressive
expansion of disposal candidates, in our view. As widely expected, AAL
confirms that the dividend is suspended in H2’15 and 2016 and the policy
moves to a payout ratio thereafter. On spot commodity prices, we calculate
AAL will be ~$250m-300m loss making in 2016-17, therefore these
announced measures should assist in restoring underlying profitability. AAL
trades on a mark to market EV/EBITDA of 9.6x in 2016 and we remain UW.

BE

 Operating and productivity improvements: AAL announced $1.1bn and
$1.0bn of cost and productivity improvements in 2016/17 which, at the
headline level, represent ~6% of our total cost base estimate in these years.
The quantum of the savings appears considerable, although we await further
clarification from management at this morning's briefing to ascertain a "like-
for-like" comparison, i.e. excluding the impact of volume, FX and energy
prices.

11:12 am
BE

 Disposal target increased: Targeting total disposals of $4bn, up from “at
least $3bn” previously. AAL now explicitly includes niobium and
phosphates for sale (JPMe ~$1bn), which we had flagged previously (note
here), and which we believe could attract a wide variety of interested parties
due to the cash generative nature and the fact they are in the fertiliser sector
where growth remains relatively strong vs most other commodities. The
remaining assets for sale (~$800m) are in platinum, copper, coal and
diamonds, for which realising full value could be difficult given current
commodity prices.

BE

 Dividend policy changed as expected: H2’15 and full year 2016 dividend
both suspended and, thereafter, AAL will move to a payout ratio. The
payout ratio has not been defined in the release and we expect further clarity
from management at the briefing this morning. The change in policy is not
significantly different from JPMe, where we had assumed an immediate
change to a payout policy (JPMe 50% of underlying earnings) although,
given the reduced earnings base in FY'16, we expected a ~50% yoy
reduction in the dividend next year.

BE

Here's that capex chart.

11:13 am
BE

PM

Sheesh

BE

Perhaps it'd be cruel to note that Mark Cutifani is taking on a lot of structural change here.

11:14 am
PM

What you saying he's not up to it?

BE

I'm only noting that the share price performance over his tenure doesn't suggest a great deal of confidence that he's up to it.

PM

hmm

11:15 am
PM

Not sure the mess is of his making

BE

Not sure about that.

BE

Anglo might've been more defensive than the average miner.

11:17 am
BE

Sure, South Africa's a mire. But diamonds are diamonds. Even with Russia coming in and eroding your monopoly, it's diamonds are still the only commodity where you basically get to make up your own price.

BE

And Anglo screwed that up, by running De Beers for cash to support its systemically broken South African side.

PM

Yeah, this is all true

11:18 am
BE

The result, over Cutifani's tenure, is a share price that's gone from £20 to 338p live.

BE

Let me see if I can find a buyer down here. Otherwise, this all sounds like kicking an invalid.

PM

hahahaha

11:19 am
PM

Sure does

BE

Uh, Goldman seller. UBS neutral. CS neutral ... I'll find one, hang on.

PM

...

11:20 am
BE

Citi neutral, RBC neutral .....

BE

Might have to come back to you on this one.

undefined
11:21 am
PM

Need to find something to lift the mood Bryce

BE

Hm.

PM

Something upbeat

11:21 am
PM

Grocers?

PM

Sainsbury, Tesco and Morrisons up there on top of the footsie leader board

PM

Pre-xmas rally

11:22 am
PM

What's behind this?

BE

eah, Stifel's pushing Sainsbury, which certainly helps.

BE

There's also an HSBC upgrade of Morrison, solely on valuation.

11:23 am
BE

Former first.

BE

Sainsbury is the cheapest of the three large cap UK food retailers on earnings
multiples, despite consistently delivering the best operating performance. It
also trades on an attractive March 2018E (clean, post property disposals) FCF
yield of 8.6%. The market, then, is implicitly pricing in downside to its
industry-leading margins. We think this is not merited. While we think that the
outlook for industry margins is a dull one, we think the chances of a
third-party-led significant further correction are slim and, that competitors'
recovery efforts will continue to make little impact on Sainsbury's relatively
strong underlying sales growth. Pricing Sainsbury's on a 7% March 2018E
FCF yield drives a 300p target price, 27% upside potential including the
dividend. Hence our upgrade to Buy from Hold.

BE

And in terms of the sector ..........

11:24 am
BE

UK food retail share prices are back near relative lows, with H1's optimism
eroded by H2 macro industry data showing very weak spending trends and Big
4 recovery efforts stalling. We think there is some room for shorter-term
optimism as a number of the structural pressures driving Big 4 share loss
should ease over the key Christmas trading period. Moreover, sector share
prices look well-underpinned by free cash flow metrics. We think Sainsbury's
should be the key beneficiary of this while we are concerned that Tesco's
relative LfL might be held back by its now cleaner, less promotionally-fuelled
trading strategy bumping up against a very high level of activity this time last
year.

BE

There's also a huge Bernstein note on the sector. But it's Bernstein, so any attempt to summarise it won't do it justice.

BE

A brief scan suggests it's pro Sainsbury, which had done well on pricing brands (now matching Tesco, more or less)

11:27 am
BE

.... while using its better reputation to edge up the price of own-brand stuff. Which seems a very sensible strategy.

BE

Overall the branded price gap between the big-4 has fallen to just 4.1%. Tesco is at the top of that pricing range but its 'brand guarantee' will help improve price perception and reality on branded goods.

BE

But that's enough positive.

undefined
BE

Entertainment One mentioned on the right.

BE

Now down about 20% on Monday's debt refinancing

PM

goodness

BE

At an effective rate of more than 7% APR.

BE

Which is rather expensive, to state the obvious, and seems to have attracted some attention to E1's difficulty in generating actual cash.

11:30 am
BE

Which I'll come to in a moment.

BE

First, though, I've always been curious about Entertainment One's film business.

BE

Which was going to be its growth engine, until it wasn't.

11:31 am
PM

I thought Peppa Pig was their big thing

PM

It is, in terms of revenues. But management doesn't want to bet everything on under-fives.

11:32 am
BE

Which is fair enough, as under fives have hardly any disposable income and can't tell official merchandise from grey-market knockoffs.

BE

In terms of being consumers, under fives are basically useless.

BE

Anyway, back to films.

11:33 am
BE

I went looking for E1's current roster this morning.

PM

Welcome

BE

The UK "Now playing" page shows nothing.

11:33 am
PM

oh dear

BE

Meaning you have to look at the "coming soon" slate, which shows a lot of stuff that's come and gone ...

BE

It's there you'll find The Last Witch Hunter, a Vin Diesel vehicle (released October 23, scores 34% on Metacritic.)

11:33 am
BE

Miss You Already, a Drew Barrymore vehicle (released September 24, scores 59% on Metacritic)

BE

Christmas with the Coopers, a John Goodman-Diane Keaton vehicle (released December 1; initial reviews not promising.)

BE

And Gascoigne, a documentary about Paul Gascoigne (which was released June 8, 2015, and was called "the ultimate vanity project" by the Telegraph).

11:34 am
BE

Now, Entertainment One often complains about the state of cinema generally.

BE

As in, there are too many blockbusters so their movies tend to be overlooked.

BE

Or there are too few blockbusters so overall attendances are down.

11:34 am
BE

Which has recently led E1 to cut film investment by £100m, or 16%

BE

Quality won't suffer, though. Which is a relief.

BE

Now, given the recent focus on the unique way in which a lot of movies are funded ....

11:35 am
BE

As in, http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3tdCGYHVz

BE

... I'm interested in the timing of E1's tactical withdrawal from the turkey market.

PM

hahaha

11:36 am
BE

Anyway, here's Peel Hunt to talk figures on the debt refi.

BE

The changes are significant, reflecting some quite major variations in revenue and costs. Revenue costs and investment all move by c£100m. In addition to trading changes, there has been a debt refi programme. With no sign of a move to cash inflows in the forecastable future, we move to Reduce with a TP of 200p. The shares look inexpensive but the propensity for major swings in elements of the forecasts is high. This undermines the good track record of delivery at the net level. The refinance process further damages the equity story unfortunately so soon after the rights issue.

BE

Interim changes: There have been some big moves in the forecasts. The interim EBITDA was pleasing, but buoyed by accounting changes and unlooked-for provision releases associated with Peppa Pig. At the pre-finance level it would appear not much has changed. However, behind this the immediate revenue and costs have shrunk.

11:36 am
BE

Refinancing: Entertainment One has, subsequent to the interims, announced a refinance programme. The company previously had a senior debt facility on which it paid a 4.3% interest rate. It is replacing this facility with a £285m senior note, due December 2022. The coupon is 6.875%. Additionally ETO will continue with IPF funding and will also retain a £100m RCF. The impact will be a significantly higher debt cost.

BE

Peel Hunt view: It doesn’t seem long ago that the company commentary on funding was that senior debt would be extinguished in the near future. Here we are with the creation of a seven-year £285m senior note. The cost of this is significantly above the debt it replaces. This refi package follows on from the rights issue that funded the additional Peppa Pig acquisition and raised an additional £60m on top. And still we expect Entertainment One to be free cash flow negative in aggregate over the next three years.

BE

The conclusion is basically that E1 isn't the kind of thing anyone should be investing a client's money in.

11:37 am
BE

• An EV calculation should consider all debt – not just senior debt. We see IPF loans as a funding structure, not a working capital item, although we recognise that it will vary at period-ends or on a transaction subject to product delivery.
• We believe the mismatch between interest cost and balance sheet debt is sufficiently great to merit reflection in the valuation process. The recent £285m senior note proposal speaks to this structurally higher debt.
• Similarly, the value of minorities needs to be captured in the enterprise value.
• While Entertainment One has seen consistent development in adjusted EBITDA and EPS, there have been some very material swings in components of forecasts. We understand that the senior management of the company is focused on EBITDA as a key KPI. Nonetheless, the significant movements in expectations of revenue and investment undermine the sentiment benefits of a stable EBITDA line.

PM

So it seems

PM

hence

11:38 am
Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 153.36, down 23.04 (-13.06%), High: 176.50, Low: 150.30, Volume: 1.99m
BE

On the balance side, here's Investec.

BE

Shares are down on possible short and stop loss activity after what looks an expensive debt refinance. However, our Investec debt analysts suggest this is not an unreasonable rate for a B+ credit rating. The refinance also extends term and financing visibility in a rising interest rate environment with more B/S flexibility for growth. With sentiment reaching new lows on short-term momentum selling, we see good long-term value on a CY16E P/E of 9x and adj. EV/EBITDA of c. 7x. Adj. catalogue value is c. £800m vs EV at c. £1bn.

New £285m senior secured note issued at 6.875% to 2022 replaces the previous January 2018 $504m bank facility. A new £100 revolver is also expected.
Forecasts – FY16/17E EPS is -2%/-6% to 19.3p/19.6p incl. share option charges. New facility at 6.875% vs previous bank debt at c. 5% adds c. £7m FY net finance charges (£6m pure interest plus arrangement fee amortisation) to take our FY17E interest to £21m (£14m before).
Why now? ETO has clearly signposted its desire to tie down long-term debt financing. ETO would need to refinance its existing facility in the next 6M vs rising UK/US interest rates implying that the sensible course is to go early.
Why not roll bank debt? This is increasingly complex to syndicate given higher fixed debt, and rising interest rates are unhelpful. Also, the bond is covenant light and has no repayment ratchet. Our debt analysts suggest ‘vanilla’ 5 year spread rates at 300-400bps over LIBOR (c. 100bps) with another 150bps for a 5 year fixed swap (180 bps/7 years). This would still imply 6% plus net.
Fairly priced in debt market terms – as an equity analyst, the bond coupon looks high, but our debt analysts see the coupon as fair and arguably at the low end given the size, lack of track record and a B+ credit rating. If we reference international media indices (550bps spread over gilts) and B+ investment grade (510bps premium) on a 7 year gilt (145bps), this implies closer to a 7% coupon requirement – we understand the price guide was over 7%, but good demand brought this in. The recent comparable UK mid cap media transaction is Perform’s £175m 2020 secured loan note at 8.5%, so higher than ETO.

11:38 am
BE

Take your pick.

Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 439.75, down 55.75 (-11.25%), High: 498.00, Low: 412.50, Volume: 351.30k
BE

Numis "withdraws"

11:40 am
BE

Can't face putting a recommendation on it any more.

BE

Numis is shop to IG Group, which has the same analyst team (Goslin-McCann-Hamilton) doing the numbers.

PM

Nie to see Numis finally catching up

11:41 am
BE

Some tinfoil hatted types have said this morning, "Ah! But Numis is shop to a competitor!"

BE

Well, kinda.

BE

One could see it that Numis, knowing the IG business inside out, have a reasonable understanding of how Plus might work.

11:42 am
BE

One could also argue that Plus and IG aren't really competitors. One's a broker and the other is a casino, except it's a wacky kind of casino where the dealer gets to pick the cards you're dealt.

PM

ouch

BE

Unusually, Numis has written eight pages on why it's suspending coverage.

11:42 am
BE

Here's the first of them.

BE

Although the recent quarterly numbers have been surprisingly strong, we believe the risks remain very much towards the downside due to the significant number of uncertainties. In particular, increasing regulatory scrutiny creates a significant risk which, in our view, is likely to have a material impact on Plus500's growth, profitability and potentially even the markets in which it can operate. Given the severity of these issues, we will now be ceasing coverage.

BE

1. What exactly went wrong and can it happen again: We believe investors should be told what exactly went wrong, what has been changed, what measures have been put in place to ensure such events do not happen again and whether these measures have now been implemented across its other subsidiaries.
2. Where there is smoke, there is often fire: Given at least one problem has already been found with Plus500's low cost, low-touch, electronic operating model, we believe there is a significant risk other problems could be found in its client onboarding procedures (suitability, KYC), client management systems (best execution) or risk management controls (client fund segregation).
3. Increasing regulatory scrutiny: Plus500 stated that it has become the subject of increased scrutiny and received further requests for information from its regulators. In our view, this is the key risk for Plus500 as increased scrutiny from any of its regulators may seriously impacts its ability to continue to operate within regulated markets.
4. What is happening at Plus500UK: Although management state they are not currently under any regulatory "restrictions", we wonder why Plus500UK is still unable to accept new clients. Perhaps the master plan is to redirect all European clients to Cyprus, close the UK subsidiary and avoid the FCA?

11:43 am
BE

5. We believe fines/penalties are on their way: In our view, there is a significant risk the FCA may look to impose fines/penalties for, amongst other issues, allowing so many clients to trade on its platform without having provided the necessary information and documentation.
6. We believe management communication needs to improve: We believe management needs to improve the consistency of messaging, provide more details on client onboarding procedures/risk management controls and to be clearer regarding regulatory relationships in order to improve the perception of Plus500 within the City.
7. What is the bull case: We believe a bull investor would point to the robust quarterly performance, a lack of any further regulatory announcements, its $20m buyback and payment of an interim dividend as signs that the business is in a strong position. While we do agree recent performance has been surprisingly strong, we wonder if this has anything to do with the fact that the majority of revenues are now being generated in Cyprus where the regulatory oversight may not be as stringent as it is in the UK.

PM

But why suspend coverage? You just say sell surely

BE

Because you don't want to cover it any more, I imagine. You have better things to do.

11:43 am
PM

Ok

PM

If we suspended coverage of stocks we didn't like, it would be damn quiet on here

BE

True.

11:44 am
undefined
BE

Oh, should also mention Lancashire.

PM

Top of the 250 board

11:46 am
BE

Having slumped 12% yesterday after Insurance Insider broke the news that the CEO and CFO had exited Cathedral, which is Lancashire's Lloyd's syndicate.

BE

No statement confirming either yesterday or today, which seems to have confused people.

BE

Such as Canaccord.

11:46 am
BE

[W]e are surprised there has been no statement this morning from the Company. IR would only say y'day that there were no issues with Cathedral's reserves or strategy. Given the high profile of the Cathedral CEO, we think his departure would be followed by others, which would impact its franchise and earnings outlook, albeit it would come at a period of shrinking to preserve profitability. It also would make Lancashire as a whole less attractive to a potential acquiror, in our view. On current forecasts, Lancashire trades on 11x 16E PE and 1.7x 15E tangible NAV, both discounts to Lloyd's peers, but for a business whose end-markets are declining rapidly, with the Special dividend paid recently

BE

Okay, so speaking generally .... It's normal when you have the potential for a constructive dismissal case, you don't say anything.

BE

You can't, in fact. You just hope the press doesn't pick up on the exits and put you in a difficult position.

11:48 am
PM

You reckon that's happened here?

BE

I reckon, yes.

BE

I also reckon the Cathedral management didn't really get on with the Lancashire management.

11:50 am
BE

I listened back to the results conference call from a month ago, which had the Cathedral CEO.

BE

He only got to answer one question. All a bit awkward.

BE

Anyway, the suggestion here is that Lancashire are moving to clean out the old guard at Cathedral. It's brutal, certainly, what with the sudden departure of two founders. But doesn't suggest any underlying problems at the business.

11:51 am
BE

Yet.

BE

Though, risk is elevated.

@chad_john: Utilitywise AGM's next week, isn't it? Haven't heard anything this morning.

PM

Will Neil Campling ever leave off Pearson?

11:56 am
Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 760.50, down 18 (-2.31%), High: 778.50, Low: 753.50, Volume: 959.71k
PM

Pearson competitor Graham last night in NYC spoke of the continuing challenging regulatory environment for private sector higher education. While no surprise, given we have highlighted the same for many months, the tone from Graham’s CEO was that the challenges are compounded by economic and competitive climate issues and are ongoing. To make matters worse, English language is now in a down cycle. Graham and Houghton have been much more forthcoming in announcing the multiple headwinds faced by the education market than rival Pearson.

First there was HE (Higher Education). Then came K-12. Next was China. Last week it was technical education (UTI has fallen 40% since warning). And yet there is just a moderate slowdown expected for Pearson? We doubt it. We suspect October's veiled warning from the company was the appetizer, with the entrée likely early in the new year.

Pearson have completed the sale of its best performing asset, the FT, this month enabling the ambitions of CEO Fallon to achieve the ‘dream’ of becoming a pure play education stock. As such the company should be valued against education peers. Which just serves to highlight how expensive the stock remains. Now trading on 10.6x F12M EV/EBITDA versus Grand Canyon on 6.5x, Apollo 0.45x, Capella 4.3x, Devry 3.8x, Graham 7x, K12 3.3x, American Public Ed 4.3x, UTI 4.3x respective F12M EV/EBITDA multiples. So Pearson is more than 2x the valuation of the average group 4.25x multiple, and that is assuming the current valuation stacks up and numbers have bottomed. We don’t think they have, and so remain a seller.

PM

Aviate still selling
